docs.lead_paragraph: A landmark government-financed study that compared drugs used to treat schizophrenia has confirmed what many psychiatrists long suspected: newer drugs that are highly promoted and widely prescribed offer few -- if any -- benefits over older medicines that sell for a fraction of the cost. The study, which looked at four new-generation drugs, called atypical antipsychotics, and one older drug, found that all five blunted the symptoms of schizophrenia, a disabling disorder that affects three million Americans. But almost three-quarters of the patients who participated stopped taking the drugs they were on because of discomfort or specific side effects.

headline.main: Study Finds Little Advantage In New Schizophrenia Drugs

docs.snippet: A landmark study has found that newer, highly promoted drugs offer few  if any  benefits over older medicines that sell for a fraction of the cost.

multimedia.credit: New generation drugs forschizophrenia offer littlebenefit over an older drug,a large governmentfinancedstudy found.
multimedia.caption: Is Newer Better?

docs.lead_paragraph: Last December, James R. Houghton, then Corning's chief executive, and Wendell P. Weeks, his heir apparent, dropped by the local chapter of the American Flint Glass Workers Union for some informal Christmas cheer. Stephen A. Mandell Sr., president of the chapter, recalls making an offhand remark about quality problems at one of Corning's Steuben glass plants.

headline.main: Hot Product Has Corning Thriving and Wary

docs.abstract: Profile of Corning Inc focuses on its new glass products for flat-panel televisions and computers, its investments into various glasses for use in medical and pharmaceutical fields and pollution control devices for diesel cars and trucks that Corning expects will be huge sellers when diesel laws start taking effect in 2007; chief executive Wendell P Weeks and president Stephen A Mandell Sr comment; photos (M)
docs.snippet: The hardest job facing Corning's new chief executive is to figure out how to eke every cent from the booming market in glass for flat-panel televisions and computers.

docs.lead_paragraph: At 1:45 in the morning one day this past July, Bono, the lead singer for U2 and the world's foremost agitator for aid to Africa, was in a van heading back to his hotel in Edinburgh from Murrayfield Stadium; he had just performed in, and expounded at, a concert designed to coincide with the beginning of the summit meeting of the major industrialized nations, held nearby at the Gleneagles resort. Despite the hour, practically everybody in the van was on a cellphone. The bodyguard in the front seat was calling the hotel to see if a huge crowd would still be camped outside hoping to catch a glimpse of their world-straddling hero. (Roger that.) Lucy Matthew, the head of the London office of DATA, Bono's policy and advocacy body -- the acronym stands for Debt AIDS Trade Africa -- was whispering to some contact in the States. And Bono, who had been conferring 12 hours earlier at Gleneagles with President George Bush, Prime Minister Tony Blair and Chancellor Gerhard Schröder, was sharing an anxiety attack with a friend. The leaders of the G-8, as the group is known, were going to offer far less in aid and trade to developing nations in Africa than the activists had led their followers to expect. Thousands of bright-eyed young recruits to the cause were going to go home in disgust.
docs.snippet: In his global campaign against disease and destitution, Bono has taken the power of rock celebrity to new places. But the success he has had is about a lot more than his soaring voice.

byline.original: By James Traub       'And I did get them to laugh. Then I tried to inspire them.'; Bono was able to dislodge conservatives from their isolationist or free-market reflexes by reaching them as Christians. Conservative Christians are now a key constituency in Africa debates; Bono helped them across the ideological divide.; The Bush administration remains distant from the rough international consensus on development issues. 'There could be a few black eyes for us...and criticism of working too close with these characters,' Bono said. 'But I'm sure it was the right thing to do.'

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 For Afghans, Voting Is A Life-or-Death Matter Nearly four years after the Taliban government was routed from Afghanistan by American-led forces, a newly emboldened insurgency has stepped up a campaign of threats and thuggery on the eve of the country's parliamentary and provincial elections, particularly in the badlands of the country's south. A1 A candidate was shot and two of her supporters were kidnapped while traveling in Nuristan Province only days before the Afghan national election, local officials said. The candidate, an anchorwoman on the state-run Afghan Television and Radio, was treated by American troops. A10 German Election Tightens In a speech just days before a German election that has become unexpectedly suspenseful, challenger Angela Merkel delivered a stark message: Chancellor Gerhard Schröder has failed, and his government ought to be thrown out. A3 North Korea Insists on Reactor North Korea refused to drop a new demand that the outside world build it a nuclear reactor before it dismantles its nuclear weapons, leaving the negotiations on the verge of collapse. A3 Iran May Offer Nuclear Solution President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran said his country would present ''new proposals'' in a weekend speech to break the impasse over Iran's nuclear programs. A11 Sharon Finally Speaks to U.N. Speaking to the United Nations General Assembly for the first time in his long career, Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel challenged the Palestinians to demonstrate their commitment to peace now that Israel had completed its Gaza withdrawal. A6 Israel's highest court ruled that part of Israel's West Bank separation barrier had imposed major hardships on Palestinian villagers and must be rerouted. A6 NATIONAL A12-25 Bush Calls for Rebuilding Storm-Ravaged Region President Bush called for the rebuilding of the Gulf Coast through the creation of a Gulf Opportunity Zone, a government enterprise that he said would provide help on taxes, housing and job training for the victims of Hurricane Katrina. A1 The drive to pour tens of billions of federal dollars into rebuilding the hurricane-battered Gulf Coast is widening a fissure among Republicans over fiscal policy. A1 More than two weeks after Hurricane Katrina devastated New Orleans and prompted a mass evacuation, Mayor C. Ray Nagin announced plans for residents and business owners to return -- at least during the daylight hours. A18 Survey Tracks Sexual Practices The National Center for Health Statistics released the government's most comprehensive survey of American sexual practices and reproductive health, delving into such sensitive areas as the prevalence of oral sex among teenagers. According to the survey, more than half of all teenagers ages 15 to 19 have engaged in oral sex. A12 Democrats Unsure of Roberts Senate Democrats are deeply conflicted about how to vote on the nomination of Judge John G. Roberts Jr. to be the nation's 17th chief justice, and appear divided about how, and whether, to use their vote to send a message to President Bush as he selects a candidate to fill a second Supreme Court vacancy. A25 Deregulation Cited in Blackouts Twenty-five months after the blackout that darkened cities from New York to Toronto and Detroit, the Energy Department and its Canadian counterpart held their first public technical discussion to talk about one factor widely considered to have been behind the episode, the deregulation of the electric system. A20 NEW YORK/REGION B1-7 Democratic Party Unites To Challenge Bloomberg The losing Democratic mayoral candidates, showing a post-primary unity that had eluded the party in New York City for years, took to the steps of City Hall to throw their support behind Fernando Ferrer. B1 Amtrak Fare Increase Is Off Amtrak officials indefinitely delayed their plans for a hefty fare increase to take effect Tuesday, after an uproar from commuters and lawmakers who use the train. B1 FASHION B9 WEEKEND E1-34;E35-42 ESCAPES F1-12 OBITUARIES B8 SPORTSFRIDAY D1-8 Displaced Athletes Recruited With Dozens of blue-chip football prospects from New Orleans and the Gulf Coast now in high schools and on playing fields from Georgia to northern Louisiana, Texas to Florida, allegations of illegal or unethical recruiting tactics among coaches are springing up. That has spurred a passionate debate on whether some of the region's most valuable exports -- its athletes -- are being exploited in the wake of Hurricane Katrina. A1 No Comeback for Armstrong Lance Armstrong, the seven-time Tour de France champion, said the firestorm over allegations that he used performance-enhancing drugs has prompted him to rule out a comeback. D1 BUSINESS DAY C1-14 NBC Seeks New Audience NBC, which dominated the prime-time ratings for a decade only to tumble to fourth place last season without them, is heavily promoting a new show called ''Three Wishes'' that is aimed, in no small part, at a churchgoing rural audience. A1 Deutsche Bank's Shelter As federal prosecutors widen their investigation into abusive tax shelters, a lawsuit indicates that Deutsche Bank had a much deeper involvement in creating and selling a questionable tax shelter. C1 Microsoft in Talks on AOL Microsoft and Time Warner have discussed a variety of possible combinations of the MSN Internet portal with Time Warner's America Online unit, including a full merger of the two businesses into a new company that would be jointly owned, according to people involved in the discussions. C1 Lengthy Sentences Debated Next week's sentencing of L. Dennis Kozlowski comes at a time when a number of lawyers are questioning whether lengthy sentences for white-collar crimes are justified. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A26-27 Editorials: Mr. Bush in New Orleans; the nuclear waste site in Utah; an election to nowhere. Columns: Paul Krugman, Thomas L. Friedman. Crossword E38 TV Listings E33 Weather A24
